text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.

6 Minute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello, and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil.
speaker: Neil

text: And I'm Rob.
speaker: Rob

text: In this program, we're talking about finance and in particular,
planning for our future lifestyles.
I can barely afford my current lifestyle!
speaker: Rob

text: But perhaps we'll pick up some good tips today.
Before that, though, a question.
Being a millionaire may be an impossible dream for most of us,
but when was the word first used in English?
Was it A, the 1600s?
B, the 1700s or C, the 1800s?
What do you think, Rob?
speaker: Neil

text: I'm going to guess that it's the 1600s
I’m going to guess that it’s the 1600s as there have always been very wealthy people.
speaker: Rob

text: Well, I'll reveal the answer later.
Now, the BBC Money Box programme covers all sorts of financial features.
Recently, they were talking about lifestyle financial planning,
which is planning your finances to meet the kind of lifestyle you want to have.
Julie Lorde leads a financial planning organisation,
and she talked about the process of lifestyle financial planning.
How many numbers does she say you need to start with?
Well, we were start by saying that we need to put together a lifetime cash flow forecast
or a model.
You just need four numbers.
Your income, your expenditure, assets, liabilities.
And then we can project forward to show you what sort of lifestyle you will have
if you do nothing at all.
And if indeed you do some of the things that perhaps an iser or a pension
or any other kind of financial product might help you with.
So how many numbers do you need?
speaker: Neil

text: She says that you start with just four numbers.
speaker: Rob

text: That's right.
The first of these numbers is your income.
This is the money that you have coming in.
Your salary, for example.
Then there's the number for your expenditure.
This is the money you have going out.
For rent, food, entertainment, transport and so on.
The next number was for assets.
This is the cash value of things that you own.
For example, property, cars, jewelry,
as well as savings and investments.
That kind of thing.
And finally, there is liabilities.
And finally there is liabilities. This is the money that you owe, for example on credit cards or loans.
speaker: liabilities

text: So if you know these details, she says they can come up with a lifetime cash flow forecast.
Which is a calculation of how much money you can expect to have in the future.
And if that is enough to meet your expectations,
do you have those details? Do you know your numbers, Rob?
I have a very detailed spreadsheet
where I do list my income and expenditure.
So I do know for a month to month how much money I need and how much I can spend.
Oh, that sounds very organized.
That sounds very organised! What does it tell you about your future?
speaker: Neil

text: Well, it just reminds me of exactly how much money I don’t have. It’s quite depressing! How about you, Neil?
speaker: Rob

text: It's quite depressing. How about you, Neil?
Oh, I live in blissful ignorance.
I have no idea how big my debts are.
I try not to worry about it.
I kind of think I'm much too young to worry about it now.
And that as if by magic, it will all work out in the end.
So it would be difficult for me to come up with those four numbers.
Anyway, let's listen to Julie Lorde again,
describing the lifestyle financial planning process.
Well, we were start by saying that we need to put together a lifetime cash flow forecast
or a model. You just need four numbers.
Your income, your expenditure, assets, liabilities.
And then we can project forward to show you what sort of lifestyle you will have
if you do nothing at all.
And if indeed you do some of the things that perhaps an isor or a pension
or any other kind of financial product might help you with.
Is lifestyle financial planning only for older people with a good pension? Not according to Julie Lord.
speaker: Neil

text: Not according to Julie Lorde?
Well, it's not all about old age, is it?
I mean, there are people we have quite a number of younger clients who come to us
and say we just want to get financially organised.
We've heard about all this stuff, these financial products.
No idea really what they are or more importantly what they're going to do for us.
So can you give us a hand to help us look forward to see what will happen?
So she also has younger clients who ask for her company’s help.
speaker: Neil

text: Yes, she uses the phrase, give us a hand, which means to help someone. If you give someone a hand, you help them.
speaker: give us a hand

text: If you give someone a hand, you help them.
Exactly. In the way that I give you a hand with six minute English.
Well, I think I give you a hand rather than the other way around, Neil.
speaker: give you a hand

text: Really, well let’s not fall out about it. Let’s listen to Julie Lord again.
speaker: Neil

text: Let's listen to Julie Lorde again.
Well, it's not all about old age, is it?
I mean, there are people we have quite a number of younger clients who come to us
and say we just want to get financially organised.
We've heard about all this stuff, these financial products.
No idea really what they are or more importantly what they're going to do for us.
So can you give us a hand to help us look forward to see what will happen?
It’s nearly time now to review our vocabulary, but first, let’s have the answer to our quiz question. When was the word millionaire first used in English? Was it:
speaker: Neil

text: When was the word millionaire first used in English?
Was it A, the 1600s, B, the 1700s or C, the 1800s?
What did you think, Rob?
speaker: Neil

text: Well, I guessed and said it was the 1600s.
speaker: Rob

text: Well, not a good guess this time. I'm afraid it's actually a lot later.
It was the 1800s when it was first used in English,
though it had appeared in French in the 1700s.
Now onto the vocabulary.
Yes, we had a lot of financial terms in this programme.
We had cash flow forecast.
This is a calculation of how much money you can expect to have
at a particular time in the future.
And the cash flow forecast is based on knowing your income,
which is the money you have coming in and your expenditure,
the money you have going out.
You also need to know your assets,
which is the value of things you own as well as savings and investments.
This is balanced against your liabilities,
which is the term for the money that you owe, for example, on credit cards.
And finally, we have the expression to give someone a hand,
meaning to help someone.
Well, that's all from us in this programme.
We look forward to your company next time.
Until then, you can find us in all the usual places on social media,
online and on our app.
Just search for BBC Learning English.
Bye.
And thanks, Rob, for giving me a hand.
No, thank you for giving me a hand. Bye!
speaker: Rob

text: Bye.
